title: R43770
content: The hidden feature of federal crimes is that helpers and offenders face the same punishment under 18 U.S.C. 2, which treats anyone who orders a federal crime with the same consequences. This secondary liability, similar to conspiracy, is based on society's fear of multiple crimes. The aiding and abetting subsection is more commonly prosecuted than the causes subsection, requiring the defendant to associate themselves with the crime and actively participate in it. Aiding and abetting involves the defendant associating with and actively participating in someone else's crime, knowing it is happening before it occurs. The defendant does not need to assist in every aspect of the offense, as even minimal involvement can lead to conviction. Aiding and abetting law dictates that involvement in a crime can be minimal, as long as the accomplice aids in some way. Knowledge without assistance or assistance without intent is not sufficient. A completed offense is necessary for conviction, but the hands-on offender does not need to be convicted for aiding and abetting. The principal had been acquitted of the charged offense. A completed offense is a prerequisite for conviction for aiding and abetting, with the defendant's involvement needing to occur before or at the time of the offense. Assistance given after the crime is a separate offense as an accessory after the fact. Sometimes accomplices can avoid federal principles of secondary criminal liability, especially when there is a substantial culpability gap between them and the primary offender. This often involves accomplices who are victims, customers, or subordinates. The Hobbs Act outlaws extortion by public officials, but victims who are willing participants in corrupt schemes may be convicted as accomplices. Customers like drinkers, bettors, johns, and drug addicts have escaped conviction as co-conspirators in certain cases. Examples from the Supreme Court show that customers of illegal establishments may not be prosecuted as aiders and abettors. The Supreme Court has ruled that customers of illegal establishments, such as speak-easies, gambling dens, and drug traffickers, cannot be prosecuted as aiders and abettors. This decision applies to cases involving unlawful activities like illegal liquor sales, gambling, and drug trafficking. The Supreme Court ruling reiterates that customers of illegal establishments, including drug traffickers, cannot be prosecuted as aiders and abettors. Federal law now punishes traffickers severely for possession with intent to distribute, while customers are typically charged with simple possession. The Gebardi case established limitations on charging individuals for conspiracy in certain circumstances related to immoral purposes. The Mann Act was limited to cases where the prostitute only acquiesced in her transportation. OSHA's provisions do not allow prosecution of employees as aiders and abettors. Subordinates of federal gambling offenders can be prosecuted, but there is no consensus on how subordinates of drug kingpins should be treated. Willfully causing an act to be done that would be an offense makes one punishable as a principal. The language of §2(b) leaves no doubt on crimes committed through an agent. Section 2(b) of the Mann Act applies to defendants who work through intermediaries, whether witting or unwitting, guilty or innocent. The intermediary's awareness of their conduct varies, but both parties must commit an underlying offense for liability to apply. Congress did not clearly state its purpose for this provision. Section 2(b) of the Mann Act imposes liability when the defendant and intermediary together commit an offense. In 1951, "causes" was changed to "willfully causes" without clear explanation. Speculation suggests the addition of "willfully" addressed a lack of mental element in §2(b). Courts interpret "willfully" as a form of intentional conduct. The courts interpret "willfully" in Section 2(b) of the Mann Act as a form of intentional conduct, where an individual causes an offense by intending the commission of a crime and using someone else to commit it. Liability can be incurred even if the individual is unaware that the conduct is a crime. Federal courts mention a withdrawal defense similar to conspiracy cases, where the defendant must demonstrate affirmative action to withdraw from aiding and abetting. In federal cases, the withdrawal defense in aiding and abetting may be limited. Liability under §2(a) is avoided if the offense is not committed due to the withdrawal of assistance. A completed offense is necessary for aiding and abetting. It is uncertain if a defendant can withdraw from aiding and abetting a crime, with varying court results on the applicability of the withdrawal defense. Proponents cite recent dicta in Rosemond to support a general withdrawal defense. The Supreme Court in Rosemond discussed the requirement for an accomplice to know of the substantive offense beforehand to be held liable. It suggested that an accomplice might be able to withdraw and escape liability before the commission of the crime. Congress has not enacted a general civil aiding and abetting statute, so there is no presumption that plaintiffs can sue aiders and abettors in addition to the main defendant. Courts have determined that aiders and abettors do not face civil liability for violations of various statutes, despite the ability of a person to sue a private defendant for such violations.
